questions.text: In patients with confirmed sialolithiasis, what is the most common location of stone formation?
questions.solution:
The most common site for salivary gland stone formation is the submandibular gland due to highly viscous secretions. 

80% of submandibular stones are radio-opaque, while parotid duct stones are usually radiolucent and rarely visible on plain radiography. Parotid gland sialography is usually required to identify the stone. A stone located in the collecting duct or within the gland may be managed by either endoscopic retrieval or lithotripsy; in rare cases, surgical removal via a parotidectomy approach may be required.

 The below USG image shows a stone in the Wharton duct of the submandibular gland.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding management considerations in a patient with submandibular gland stones?

choices.text: Surgical gland excision is the treatment of choice if patient is unresponsive to conservative management
Associated chronic sialadenitis is a contraindication for sialendoscopy
Conventional radiography is mostly useless as more than 80% of submandibular stones are radiolucent
Stones proximal to the lingual nerve can be removed via an intra-oral approach

questions.solution:
If the stone is proximal to the lingual nerve, stone retrieval can be done via an intraoral surgical approach under general anesthesia.

80% of submandibular stones are radio-opaque. Conventional radiography is useful in the initial workup of salivary stones, but ultrasound, CT, MRI, and sialendoscopy are required for accurate diagnosis and localization (especially for smaller and parenchymal stones).

The only contraindication for sialendoscopy is acute sialadenitis. This is because sialendoscopy and ductal dilation is more difficult in the setting of inflammation and there will be a greater likelihood of ductal trauma and potential spread of infection.

Management of sialolithiasis should begin with conservative measures, oral hydration, analgesia, massaging of gland, sialogogues, and antibiotics (if there are signs of infection). If unsuccessful, the next step is based on the sialolith's size, number, and location:

  • Small stones (<4mm) - endoscopic removal using Dormia basket.
  • larger stones - external shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) + fragment removal or  Open surgery and stone removal
  • Surgical excision of the gland should always be a last resort

If distal to lingual nerve: Make a longitudinal incision over the duct. Remove the stone. Suture the duct using absorbable suture.     

If proximal to lingual nerve: intraoral approach  

The image below shows a stone in the submandibular salivary duct.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented with complaints of recurrent bilateral painless swelling over the parotid glands. FNAC done showed acinar cell hypertrophy without any inflammatory signs.  All of the following are associated with this condition except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and FNAC report of acinar hypertrophy are suggestive of sialadenosis. Hyperthyroidism is not associated with sialadenosis.

Sialosis (sialadenosis) is defined as an asymptomatic, non-inflammatory, non-neoplastic parenchymal salivary gland disease. It is accompanied by a persistent painless bilateral swelling of the salivary glands, most commonly involving the parotid glands. Most cases of sialadenosis are observed in patients between 40 to 70 years of age, and the salivary gland swellings are often soft and symmetrical. On FNAC, acinar cell hypertrophy is seen without any inflammatory signs.

Sialadenosis is associated with the following conditions:

  1. Nutritional disorders
    • Bulimia nervosa
    • Vitamin deficiency
  2. Endocrine disorders
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hypothyroidism
  3. Metabolic disorders
    • Obesity
    • Cirrhosis
    • Malabsorption
  4. Autoimmune disorders 
    • Sjögren disease 
  5. Drug-induced 
    • Valproic acid
    • Thiourea
  6. Pregnancy
  7. Alcoholism

questions.text: A 40-year-old man on routine dental checkup was found to have the following finding on orthopantomogram. What is the reason for the finding marked with the arrow?
questions.solution:
The given orthopantomogram shows a right-sided clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion suggestive of a stafne bone cyst. It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue.

It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of the mandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle. It is more common in males. Usually, no treatment is required.

A dentigerous cyst is a cyst in relation to an unerupted tooth. Most commonly involves the 3rd molar. It is managed by enucleation and removal of the tooth.

questions.text: A 5 year-old-boy was brought to the OPD by his parents with a painless, soft, translucent swelling under the tongue. On examination, the swelling is as seen below. Which of the following statements best describe his condition?

choices.text: Mucous retention cyst from a minor salivary gland
Mucous extravasation cyst from sublingual gland
Mucous extravasation cyst from a minor salivary gland
Mucous retention cyst from sublingual gland

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image points to a diagnosis of an oral ranula. It is a mucous extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland.

Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog. It is of two types:

  • Oral ranula - It is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving the sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination fluctuation test and transillumination test is positive. It is conservatively managed by marsupialisation. Definitive management is excision of the cyst. Some may resolve spontaneously.
  • Cervical or plunging ranula- is a rare type of retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland. The mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm to enter the neck. Clinically present as intraoral and cervical swelling. Diagnosis is made by USG or MRI. Management includes excision of  sublingual gland + aspiration of saliva out of the sac.

 

Note: Oral ranulas located in the floor of the mouth can often be confused with an epidermoid cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding salivary gland tumors?

choices.text: 90% of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant
The submandibular gland is the most common site for salivary tumors
Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland
A salivary gland tumor with perineural invasion is mucoepidermoid carcinoma

questions.solution:
90% of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, and the common sites are the upper lip, palate, and retromolar regions.

Option B: The most common site for salivary tumors is the parotid gland, mostly involving the superficial lobe.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known to be associated with perineural invasion.

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

Type of Salivary gland

Location

Frequency of tumor

Percentage of malignancy

Major

Parotid

Common

10–20%
 

Submandibular

Uncommon

50%
 

Sublingual

Very rare

85%

Minor

Upper aero-digestive tract

Rare

90%

questions.text: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
A slowly progressive swelling, with a variable consistency, lifting the ear lobe, is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumor, primarily affects the parotid gland, particularly its superficial lobe. It is also referred to as a mixed tumor due to its combination of epithelial and mesenchymal components. This tumor most commonly occurs in females around the age of 40.

Clinical features:

  • Painless, slow-growing swelling
  • Lobulated, firm, variable in consistency
  • Lifts the earlobe
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone.
  • In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils, and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.
  • Features of malignancy - a sudden increase in size, ulceration of the overlying skin, facial nerve palsy (involvement of facial nerve), painful swelling, and restriction of jaw movements.

Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the investigation of choice in diagnosing pleomorphic adenoma. Open biopsy is contraindicated due to the chances of injury to the facial nerve.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy. Radical parotidectomy is performed for malignant pleomorphic adenoma.

Other options:

Option A: Adamantinoma is a low-grade malignant tumor that usually presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling since it most commonly affects the tibial diaphysis.

Option B:  Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:

  1. Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development.
  2. Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct
  3. Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma
  4. Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)

Option D: Sebaceous cysts are retention cysts of the sebaceous glands that present as smooth, non-tender, non-transillumination swelling with a punctum (in 70% of the patients). 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

Type of Salivary gland

Location

Frequency of tumor

Percentage of malignancy

Major

Parotid

Common

10–20%
 

Submandibular

Uncommon

50%
 

Sublingual

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with painless swelling in front of the left ear for the past 2 years. On examination, her left earlobe was lifted and the curtain sign was positive. Which of the following is false about the condition?

choices.text: Treatment of choice is total radical parotidectomy
Malignant form shows LMN facial palsy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma. The treatment of choice is superficial parotidectomy. 

Clinical features:

  • Painless, slow-growing swelling
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency
  • Lift the ear lobe
  • Free from deeper structures
  • With no facial nerve involvement
  • Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone

Pleomorphic adenoma involves the superficial lobe of parotid gland and should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.

Types of Parotidectomy

  • If only the superficial lobe is involved: 
    • Superficial parotidectomy - only superficial lobe removed. Usually done in benign conditions.
  • If both lobes are involved:
    • Total conservative parotidectomy - both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved.
    • Total radical parotidectomy - both lobes and facial nerve removed.

Sometimes it may undergo malignant transformation. The malignant form is mixed malignant tumor or carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma (most aggressive salivary malignancy).

Signs of malignant transformation

  • A rapid increase in size
  • Pain and ulceration
  • Facial nerve involvement (LMN)
  • Lymph node involvement
  • Restricted jaw movements

questions.text: Technetium-99m pertechnetate scintigraphy done for a patient with a chronic painless facial swelling is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this tumor?

choices.text: This tumor has no malignant potential
Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice
Histology shows a double layer of epithelial cells with dense lymphoid stroma
It is the most common unilateral benign tumor of the parotid gland

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Warthin’s tumor. These tumors appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans because of the high mitochondrial content in oncocytes that incorporate technetium-99m. The most common benign tumor of the parotid gland is pleomorphic adenoma.

Warthin’s tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum usually presents as a unilateral tumor.  It is usually seen in the lower poles of the parotid and is commonly associated with smoking. It occurs most often in elderly males. It has no malignant potential.   

Histology shows tumor cells lined by a double layer of neoplastic epithelial cells resting on the dense lymphoid stroma. FNAC is the preferred investigation. Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice.

Note: Both pleomorphic adenoma and Warthin's tumors commonly present as unilateral tumors. A bilateral presentation is usually rare. However in rare cases, if there is a bilateral benign salivary tumor, the tumor is most likely to be a Warthin's tumor.

questions.text:
Match the following
 Tumor  Description

1. Godwin’s tumor

 a. Malignant salivary gland tumor

2. Eskimoma

  b. Benign lymphoepithelial tumor

3. Kuttner’s tumor

  c. Hotspot on 99Tc scintigraphy

4. Oncocytoma

  d. Chronic sclerosing sialadenitis
questions.solution:
Tumor Description
Godwin’s tumor  Benign lymphoepithelial tumor
Eskimoma  Malignant salivary gland tumor
Kuttner’s tumor  Chronic sclerosing sialadenitis
oncocytoma  Hotspot on 99Tc scintigraphy

 Godwin’s tumor 

  •  Benign lymphoepithelial tumor of the salivary gland. 
  • It is associated with CMV. 
  • < 5% shows malignancy - known as Eskimoma.

Kuttner’s tumor is chronic sclerosing sialadenitis of the submandibular gland.

Oncocytoma (oxyphil adenoma) - 

  • Usually benign, originating from oncocytes.
  • Grossly - tan-colored small, well-circumscribed, and encapsulated.
  • Microscopically - large oncocytes with swollen granular cytoplasm.
  • Appear as a hotspot on Technetium-99m pertechnetate scintigraphy due to an abundance of mitochondria.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with recent onset facial asymmetry and a lump over the roof of the mouth for the past 1 year. On examination, a solitary erythematous swelling with diffuse borders is seen over the left hard palate. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a swiss cheese pattern. Which of the following conditions is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy finding is suggestive of adenoid cystic carcinoma.  Facial asymmetry points to the perineural invasion of the tumor into the facial nerve, which is characteristic of adenoid cystic carcinoma.

It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland. It is a slow-growing tumor most commonly involving the parotid and submandibular glands. Histology shows a swiss cheese pattern. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst. 

It has a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasive growth with a high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis. The most common site of distant metastasis is the lung. Treatment involves removal of the gross tumor, with radiation therapy for the microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor involving the parotid gland?
questions.solution:
Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor, while pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.

Histological classification and incidence of tumors of salivary glands:

Benign Tumors Incidence Malignant tumors Incidence
Pleomorphic adenoma 50% Mucoepidermoid carcinoma 15%
Warthin’s tumor 5–10% Adenocarcinoma (NOS) 10%
Oncocytoma 1% Acinic cell carcinoma 5%
Other adenomas 5–10% Adenoid cystic carcinoma 5%
Basal cell adenoma  1-2% Malignant mixed tumor 3–5%
Canalicular adenoma 1%  Squamous cell carcinoma 1%
Ductal papillomas  - Other carcinomas 2%

NOS: Not otherwise specified.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: As a 1st year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identify the facial nerve trunk.  All of the following structures can be used for its localization except:
questions.solution:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as an anatomical landmark for the identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Conley's pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric- The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Mastoid process- Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.
  • Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process- The facial nerve lies superficial to it.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland
  • Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels
  • Temporal branch

The given image points to the facial nerve (marked by arrow).

questions.text:
A patient is scheduled to undergo a total parotidectomy with selective node dissection of levels Ib, IIa, IIb, and III. Which of the following groups of lymph nodes will be removed during the procedure?
  1. Submental
  2. Submandibular
  3. Middle Jugular
  4. Lower Jugular
  5. Pretracheal
questions.solution:
Among the given options, only submandibular (Level Ib) and middle jugular nodes (Level III) nodes will be removed. The other nodes that will be removed in the procedure will be upper jugular nodes (Level IIa and IIb).

Selective neck dissection has been used in the treatment of patients with cancer of the upper aerodigestive tract (oral cavity, pharynx, larynx), cancer of the thyroid gland, cutaneous malignancies, and cancer of the salivary gland. The type of selective neck dissection used varies depending on the lymphatic drainage and metastatic pattern associated with the primary cancer site.

Related Pearl: Lymph Node Levels in the Neck

Levels Description

IA

Submental

IB

Submandibular

II

Upper jugular

III

Middle jugular

IV

Lower Jugular

VA and VB

Posterior triangle group

VI

Pre tracheal

Para tracheal

Pre laryngeal

VII (Controversial)

Mediastinum (Some don’t consider it to be part of cervical nodes)

questions.text: A patient with pleomorphic adenoma is posted for submandibular gland excision. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be injured during this procedure?

choices.text: Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve

questions.solution:
The inferior alveolar nerve is the nerve least likely to be affected by submandibular surgery.

Nerves at risk for injury during removal of the submandibular gland include:

  1. Marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve
  2. Lingual nerve
  3. Hypoglossal nerve

An important landmark in submandibular gland dissection is the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle. Once identified, it can be retracted to reveal the deep lobe of the gland. The hypoglossal nerves lie deep to the submandibular capsule and should not be damaged during intracapsular dissection. The facial artery is ligated twice during the surgery.

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in Frey’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating).

Frey’s syndrome is also known as Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops after parotid surgery. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers crossed along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near the parotid region.

Clinical features are due to the result of salivary stimulation (by the smell or taste of food) leading to the sweating and flushing of the periauricular region on the involved side of the face. A starch iodine test is used for diagnosis.

Treatment ranges from antiperspirants (in mild cases) to tympanic neurectomy or botulinum toxin injection (in severe cases). It can be prevented by incorporating careful extracapsular dissection and closure of the superficial musculoaponeurotic layer during parotidectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Facial nerve is the 7th cranial nerve that supplies the muscles of the face, and results in facial paralysis if injured during parotidectomy

Option B: Oculomotor is the 3rd cranial nerve which supplies the extraocular muscles. If injured during ophthalmic surgeries, it results in ocular paralysis and the eye pointing down and out.

Option D: Glossopharyngeal nerve is the 9th cranial nerve and its injury causes loss of taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. 

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.
  LACRIMAL GLANDS SUBMANDIBULAR GLAND
SUBLINGUAL GLAND		 PAROTID GLANDS
Nucleus

Lacrimatory nucleus

Pons

Superior salivatory nucleus

Pons

Inferior salivatory nucleus

Medulla 
Carried by
Nervus intermedius
Facial nerve (VII)
Nervus intermedius
Facial nerve (VII)
Glossopharyngeal (IX)
Nerve Greater superficial petrosal nerve Chorda tympani Lesser petrosal nerve

ear through		 Facial hiatus Petrotympanic fissure/

fossa floor, exits through foramen lacerum and joins deep petrosal nerve in

Trigeminal nerve		 --- Auriculotemporal branch of Mandibular nerve (V3)

questions.text: After parotidectomy patients complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
After parotid surgery, the nerve involved in the loss of sensation while shaving is the great auricular nerve.

The great auricular nerve (GAN) originates from the second and third nerve roots of the cervical plexus (C2-C3). It supplies the skin over the lower pinna, pre-auricular region, and angle of the mandible (image below). The main trunk passes over the sternocleidomastoid and into the anterosuperior portion of the parotid glands and branches into the anterior and posterior GAN. The anterior branch of GAN is often injured during parotid surgery during the initial elevation of the skin flap.

When GAN is injured, it can cause reduced sensations in the earlobe, pre-auricular skin, and the angle of the mandible that can interfere with habits such as shaving, wearing earrings, etc.

Other options:

Option A: The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3 of trigeminal) supplies the posterior part of the temple, tragus, and adjoining auricle. It does not supply the area where a person is likely to shave. However, the injury to the auriculotemporal nerve resulting in aberrant regeneration would result in Frey's Syndrome (gustatory sweating).

Option C: Though the facial nerve is the most common nerve affected during parotidectomy, any damage would result in facial paralysis and not loss of sensation of the face.

Option D: The mandibular nerve is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) that supplies the skin over the mandible, lower lip, and cheek. However, they are not injured during parotidectomy.

questions.text: At what age should the congenital defect (shown in the image below) be ideally repaired?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a unilateral cleft lip. Repair of cleft lip (primary palate) along with associated nasal deformities is done at 3–6 months of age. 

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 3–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: A child with a cleft lip is posted for surgery. Which of the following methods is not used to repair this condition?
questions.solution:
Wardill’s method is not a method of cleft lip repair. It is a technique for hard palate closure. 

Cleft-lip repair techniques:

  • Millard’s rotation advancement technique (most common)
  • Thompson
  • Le Mesurier
  • Tennison–Randall

Techniques of hard palate closure include the use of the following:

  • Unipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the Wardill-Veau-Kilner repair 
  • Bipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the von Langenbeck repair

questions.text: Which among the following is an oral cavity lesion with a  high-risk of malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
Speckled erythroplakia has a high risk of malignant transformation.

Malignancy risk:

High-risk lesions 

Erythroplakia (homogenous/speckled) 

  •  Seen as red velvety lesions
  •  Speckled type is the most  aggressive
  •  The treatment of choice is surgical ablation 

Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia

  • A white patchy lesion that cannot be rubbed off.
  • Speckled leucoplakia has an erythematous base
  • The treatment of choice is excision

Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis

  • White patches that can be rubbed off with a hyperaemic border.
  • Management includes prolonged treatment with topical antifungals or systemic antifungal therapy. If no improvement or if there are any signs of dysplasia, surgical excision is done.

Medium risk lesions

Oral submucous fibrosis

  • Hypersensitive reaction to betel nut product.
  • Other risk factors are - tobacco, chili, vitamin deficiency 
  • Clinical features - trismus, ankyloglossia, soreness, and burning sensation in the mouth.
  • Management includes antioxidants, intralesional triamcinolone, and surgical excision.

Syphilitic glossitis

  • Associated with tertiary syphilis

Low-risk lesions

Oral lichen planus 

  • Reticulate fine lace-like pattern.
  • Management is topical corticosteroids.   

Discoid lupus erythematosus
Discoid keratosis congenita

Speckled erythroplakia:

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with complaints of difficulty in opening his mouth, restricted tongue movements, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating food. He is a smoker and chews pan masala. On examination, scarring is present in the oral cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is oral submucous fibrosis. It is a premalignant lesion of the oral cavity, in which fibrous bands are formed beneath the oral mucosa.
Risk factors are

  • Betel nut
  • Chilli
  • Tobacco
  • Vitamin deficiency

Clinical features include ankyloglossia, trismus, soreness, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating.

Management includes intralesional steroids, vitamin supplements, and surgical excision.

Option A: Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by post cricoid web that is associated with iron deficiency anemia, glossitis, and koilonychia. It usually presents as dysphagia.

Option B: Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia appears as a white patchy lesion, that cannot be rubbed off.

Option D: Erythroplakia is seen as bright red velvety plaque in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD, with a 7cm lesion over the left buccal mucosa and difficulty opening the mouth. On examination, the right cervical lymph node is 4cm in size with overlying skin involvement. What is the TNM staging of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The TNM staging in this patient is T4bN3bMX. A 7-cm primary tumor in the oral cavity with difficulty in opening mouth denotes a locally advanced tumor: T4b. Contralateral cervical lymph node involvement with skin involvement (extranodal extension-positive): N3b

Note: Here the skin invasion corresponds to ENE positive, and hence, the N staging is N3b instead of N2c (contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative).

Related Pearl: TNM staging of oral cavity cancer - AJCC 8th edition

Primary Tumour (T)
TX Cannot be assessed
Tis Carcinoma in situ
T1

Tumor ≤2 cm, depth of invasion (DOI)  ≤5 mm (DOI is depth of invasion and not tumor thickness)
T2

Tumor ≤2 cm, DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm;

or tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, and ≤10 mm DOI
T3 Tumor >4 cm or any tumor >10 mm DOI
T4 Moderately advanced or very advanced local disease
T4a

Moderately advanced local disease:

Tumor> 4 cms with DOI >10 mm

or tumor invades adjacent structures only (through cortical bone of the mandible or maxilla or involves the maxillary sinus or skin of the face.

Note that superficial erosion of bone/tooth socket (alone) by a gingival primary is not sufficient to classify a tumor as T4
T4b Very advanced local disease; tumor invades the masticator space, pterygoid plates, or skull base and/or encases the internal carotid artery

 

Regional lymph nodes (N) - Clinical
NX Cannot be assessed
N0 No regional lymph node metastasis
N1 Single ipsilateral, <3 cm and ENE (extranodal extension)‐negative
N2  Single ipsilateral lymph node larger than 3 cms but not greater than 6 cms, ENE - negative; Multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE ‐negative ;  Bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N2a Single ipsilateral lymph node larger than 3 cms but not greater than 6 cms, ENE - negative
N2b Multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE ‐negative
N2c Bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative
N3

Metastasis in a lymph node larger than 6 cms and ENE -negative or metastasis in any lymph node and clinically over ENE +positive
N3a Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cms and ENE‐negative
N3b

Metastasis in any lymph node(s) and clinically overt ENE +positive.


Note:
ENE is as determined by physical examination (e.g., invasion of the skin, infiltration of musculature/dense tethering to adjacent structures, or dysfunction of a cranial nerve, the brachial plexus, the sympathetic trunk, or the phrenic nerve) and supported by radiological evidence, should be present to assign a status of ENE‐positive.

questions.text: Identify the given incision used for maxillectomy.
questions.solution:
The image shows Weber–Ferguson incision which is used to access the floor of the maxillary sinus in the case of maxillary carcinoma.

The rest of the options are incisions used for modified radical neck dissection (MRND).

questions.text: What is this approach used in the treatment of oral cancer?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the visor approach.

In the visor approach, an incision is made extending from one end of the mandible to the opposite side and subplatysmal flaps are elevated superiorly over the mandible (like a visor of a helmet). This approach provides a wide exposure to remove larger lesions involving the anterior oral cavity that is not amenable to a peroral approach. This avoids a lip-splitting incision but has the disadvantage of anesthesia of chin/lower lip (due to the sacrifice of submental nerves).

The surgical approach selected for excision of oral cavity tumors depends on the size of the tumor, location (anterior vs posterior), proximity to bone (mandible or maxilla), and the need to perform neck dissection. The most commonly employed approaches are as follows:

  • Peroral - accessible early-stage tumors
  • Lower cheek flap - tumors requiring partial mandibulectomy or large posterolateral tumors that cannot be accessed via a peroral approach
  • Upper cheek flap - tumors requiring partial maxillectomy or those involving the hard palate, upper gum, upper gingivobuccal sulcus and anterior soft palate
  • Mandibulotomy - larger tumors of the posterior oral cavity, tumors that involve the base of the tongue or pharyngeal wall.
  • Visor flap - larger lesions of the anterior oral cavity involving the anterior floor of the mouth and lower gum that are not amenable to a peroral approach

Commando operation is the combined mandibular resection and neck node dissection. It is used mainly for carcinoma of the tongue.

questions.text: You will use an Abbe-Estlander flap for the reconstruction of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Abbé- Estlander flaps are used for the reconstruction of the lip.

They are lip switch flaps based on the sublabial or superior labial artery. When the defect involves the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for more midline defects.

Related Pearl: Lip reconstruction flaps

  • Up to half of the lip can be removed and closed primarily.
  • Defects encompassing between one half and two-thirds of the lip require augmentation.
  • Karapandzic flap consists of circumoral incisions with the circular rotation of the skin flaps while maintaining innervation.
  • When the defect involves the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for more midline defects.

questions.text: A woman from Himachal Pradesh,  presented with complaints of neck swelling for the past 1 year. On examination, a firm, non-tender, pulsatile mass was palpated on the left side of the neck. The mass is mobile from side to side, but not up and down. A carotid angiogram of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Shamblin classification is used for staging
FNAC is the initial investigation of choice

questions.solution:
The given scenario and carotid angiogram showing splaying of the bifurcation of the carotids, also known as lyre sign points to a diagnosis of chemodectoma. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is contraindicated when a chemodectoma is suspected.

Chemodectoma is also known as carotid body tumor (aka potato tumor). It is a benign tumor of the neuroendocrine tissue of the carotid body. It has a higher incidence at high altitudes because of chronic hypoxia, which leads to carotid body hyperplasia.

The tumor presents as a slowly enlarging mass that is firm, rubbery, pulsatile, mobile from side to side but not up and down. A bruit may be heard. Family history can be present in 10% of the cases. 

Shamblin classification is used for staging carotid body tumors.

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is ______.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Branchial cyst develops due to the persistence of the cervical sinus. The cervical sinus is formed when the 2nd arch mesoderm overgrows the succeeding arches and overhangs them as shown in the image. The space between the overhanging 2nd pharyngeal arch and the 3rd, 4th, and 6th arches is called the cervical sinus. The cavity of the cervical sinus is lined by ectoderm and normally gets obliterated.

Branchial cysts are usually lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid (option B). An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

questions.text: To which group of lymph nodes does a tumor limited to the glottis of the larynx spread commonly?
questions.solution:
Tumors limited to the glottis usually do not spread to any lymph nodes, as there are no lymphatics in the vocal cords. However, if the tumor invades the supra- or the infra-glottic spaces, lymph node spread can occur. 

The most common malignant tumor of the larynx is squamous cell carcinoma. Glottis is the most common site of laryngeal cancer.

questions.text: Radical neck dissection spares which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Digastric muscle is spared in radical neck dissection (RND). RND is used in the treatment of malignant lesions of the neck with local spread or metastasis. 

In 1905, Crile described RND where Level I-V LN, sternocleidomastoid (SCM), internal jugular vein (IJV), and XI cranial nerve (spinal accessory nerve) are removed.

In 1962, Suarez described modified RND (MRND) where Level I-V LNs are removed and the following are preserved:

  1. MRND I - XI cranial nerve 
  2. MRND II -  XI cranial nerve and IJV
  3. MRND III - XI cranial nerve, IJV, and SCM


Note: RND with an additional LN/muscle/nerve is called extended RND.

Related Pearl: Types of Neck Dissections

Dissection LN removed Other structures removed/preserved
RND l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed
MRND l l-V CNXI preserved
MRND ll l-V CNXI, IJV preserved
MRND lll l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM preserved
END l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed+ one/more LN groups +/- non-lymphatic structures

 

SND LN removed Primary site of cancer
Supra-omohyoid l-lll Oral cavity
Extended supra-omohyoid l-lV Oral cavity and oropharynx
Postero-lateral

ll-V

Skin over posterior scalp and upper neck
Lateral ll-lV

Oropharynx, hypopharynx, larynx
Anterior(Central) Vl Thyroid/midline structures

RND- Radical Neck Dissection; MRND- Modified Radical Neck Dissection; END- Extended Neck Dissection; SND- Selective Neck Dissection

Related Pearl: Lymph Node Levels in the Neck

Levels Description

IA

Submental

IB

Submandibular

II

Upper jugular

III

Middle jugular

IV

Lower Jugular

VA and VB

Posterior triangle group

VI

Pre tracheal

Para tracheal

Pre laryngeal

VII (Controversial)

Mediastinum (Some don’t consider it to be part of cervical nodes)

questions.text:
A patient is posted under your unit for type 2 modified radical neck dissection. Which of the following structures will you preserve during this procedure?

1. Internal jugular vein
2. Upper jugular lymph nodes
3. Sternocleidomastoid muscle
4. Posterior triangle nodes
5. Spinal accessory nerve
questions.solution:
In type 2 modified radical neck dissection (MRND), internal jugular vein and spinal accessory nerve will be preserved.

Related Pearl: Types of Neck Dissections

Dissection LN removed Other structures removed/preserved
RND l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed
MRND l l-V CNXI preserved
MRND ll l-V CNXI, IJV preserved
MRND lll l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM preserved
END l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed+ one/more LN groups +/- non-lymphatic structures

 

SND LN removed Primary site of cancer
Supra-omohyoid l-lll Oral cavity
Extended supra-omohyoid l-lV Oral cavity and oropharynx
Postero-lateral

ll-V

Skin over posterior scalp and upper neck
Lateral ll-lV

Oropharynx, hypopharynx, larynx
Anterior(Central) Vl Thyroid/midline structures

RND- Radical Neck Dissection; MRND- Modified Radical Neck Dissection; END- Extended Neck Dissection; SND- Selective Neck Dissection
